title: 109_hr5948
content:
The Act titled "Belarus Democracy Reauthorization Act of 2006" amends the Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 due to ongoing human rights violations and flawed democratic governance in Belarus, particularly highlighted by the 2006 presidential elections that failed to meet international standards. The regime of Aleksandr Lukashenka in Belarus has maintained power through illegal means, including orchestrating an unconstitutional referendum to impose a new constitution and abolish the duly-elected parliament. The government has also failed to address cases of disappeared opposition figures and journalists, with credible evidence linking top officials to these disappearances. Political opposition figures have faced persecution under Lukashenka's regime. The Lukashenka regime in Belarus has imprisoned political activists and maintained control over the country's information space, targeting independent media and suppressing freedom of speech. The authorities have also cracked down on civil society through harassment and closure of organizations, while minority religious communities face harassment and heavy fines. The Belarusian authorities have silenced dissent through retribution against activists with threats, firings, expulsions, beatings, and intimidation. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to call for the release of political prisoners, support democracy, human rights, and sovereignty in Belarus. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to support democratic movements, end tyranny, reject flawed elections, and promote integration into the European community. Assistance is provided to promote democracy and civil society in Belarus, focusing on freedom, democracy, and human rights. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to support democratic movements, emphasizing free, fair, and transparent elections, and the development of a democratic political culture and civil society. Activities supported include expanding independent media broadcasting within Belarus and supporting nonstate-controlled media facilities. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to support democratic movements by aiding civil society, human rights defenders, democratic political parties, and transparent electoral processes. Authorization of appropriations is also updated for 2007 and 2008. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to include radio and television broadcasting to Belarus, as well as sanctions against the government of Belarus. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to include sanctions against the government of Belarus until specific conditions are met, including the release of political prisoners, withdrawal of legal charges against activists, accounting for disappearances of opposition leaders, and cessation of harassment against independent media and organizations. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to include sanctions against the government of Belarus until specific conditions are met, including prosecution of fraudulent elections, accounting for embezzlement of state assets, and holding free and fair elections under international supervision. Additionally, the President may deny entry into the United States for senior Belarusian government officials and their immediate family members. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 includes sanctions against the government of Belarus for benefiting from policies undermining democracy. Prohibition on loans and investments from the US government is recommended, except for humanitarian goods. Multilateral financial assistance is also restricted. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 imposes sanctions on the Belarus government for undermining democracy. It prohibits US government loans and investments, except for humanitarian aid. Multilateral financial assistance to Belarus is also restricted, with the US Executive Director of international financial institutions instructed to oppose any extension of financial assistance to the Belarus government. The Act also recommends blocking assets owned by the Belarus government or closely linked individuals. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 imposes sanctions on the Belarus government for undermining democracy, including electoral fraud and human rights abuses. It prohibits US government loans and investments, restricts multilateral financial assistance, and recommends blocking assets of the Belarus government and associated individuals. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 imposes sanctions on the Belarus government, including blocking assets of the government and senior leadership, restricting exports to government entities, and prohibiting US persons from supporting government-operated businesses. Expenses for maintaining blocked property must be covered by the property owners. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 imposes sanctions on the Belarus government, including blocking assets of the government and senior leadership. Expenses for maintaining blocked property must be covered by the property owners. Prohibitions do not apply to certain humanitarian assistance to Belarus. Violations of these restrictions may result in penalties under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Definitions for terms like 'air carrier' and 'United States person' are provided in this subsection. SEC. 7. MULTILATERAL COOPERATION.
    Section 7 of the Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to support comprehensive cooperation.
SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS.
    Section 9(3) of the Act is amended to include additional definitions for key roles and individuals. The Belarus Democracy Act of 2004 is amended to include a new clause targeting public corruption in Belarus.
